questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with headaches and transient blurred vision. Fundoscopy reveals optic disc swelling with indistinct margins and engorged veins. What is the most accurate explanation for the pathogenesis of this condition?

options.A: Compression of the central retinal vein.
options.B: Increased CSF pressure causes axoplasmic stasis.
options.C: Inflammation of the optic nerve head.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Increased CSF pressure causes axoplasmic stasis. Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests Papilledema, a hydrostatic, non-inflammatory condition characterised by swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. Typically bilateral, it occurs because the optic nerve, encased in the meningeal sheaths, is affected by changes in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure. Pathogenesis: Initially thought to be caused by compression of the central retinal vein, leading to its collapse while the artery remains intact. (Option A ruled out) Current Understanding: Blockage of axoplasmic transport in the optic nerve head due to elevated CSF pressure results in optic disc swelling and vascular changes on the disc surface. Aetiology (Common causes): Intracranial tumors (e.g., mid-brain, parieto-occipital region, cerebellum). Brain abscesses, cavernous sinus thrombosis, aneurysms, subarachnoid haemorrhage. Pseudotumour cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension). Malignant hypertension is typically accompanied by increased intracranial pressure. Decrease in intraocular pressure (Option D ruled out) Symptoms: Early symptoms: Transient blurred vision or blackouts. Progression: Enlarged blind spots, visual field contraction, and severe vision loss. Headache often worsens in the morning and improves during the day. Nausea, vomiting, and diplopia may also occur. Inflammation of the optic nerve head (Option C) describes optic neuritis, which involves inflammation leading to swelling and visual symptoms. In contrast, papilledema is caused by increased intracranial pressure affecting axoplasmic flow rather than direct inflammation of the optic nerve head. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Page 839,841,842

questions.question: Latent nystagmus is seen in which of the below mentioned condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Infantile esotropia Explanation: Latent nystagmus is associated with infantile esotropia. With both eyes open, there is no nystagmus, but horizontal nystagmus becomes apparent on covering one eye. The fast phase is in the direction of the uncovered fixating eye. Occasionally, an element of latency may be superimposed on a manifest nystagmus so that when one eye is covered, the amplitude of nystagmus increases (manifest-latent nystagmus). Dissociated vertical deviation is another feature of Infantile esotropia. (Option B) Arnold-Chiari malformation is associated with Downbeat nystagmus (Vertical nystagmus with the fast phase beating downwards, more easily elicited in lateral gaze and downgaze). (Option C) Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is associated with Ataxic nystagmus (Horizontal jerk nystagmus that occurs in the abducting eye of a patient with an INO). (Option D) Cerebellopontine angle tumours are associated with Bruns nystagmus (Coarse cerebellar horizontal jerk nystagmus in one eye and fine high-frequency vestibular nystagmus in the other) Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page 812, 813.

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with impaired adduction of the left eye on rightward gaze, and the abducting eye shows ataxic nystagmus. There is no noticeable ptosis, and the convergence remains intact. MRI shows a lesion in the brainstem affecting the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Internuclear ophthalmoplegia Explanation: This patient’s presentation, with impaired adduction of the left eye and the abducting eye shows ataxic nystagmus, along with the intact convergence and MRI findings, is consistent with internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) Injury to the MLF between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral oculomotor nerve’s medial rectus subnucleus. Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye, with slow or absent adduction during lateral gaze. The abducting eye overshoots the target (dysmetria), resulting in disconjugate nystagmus. Convergence is typically preserved. Bilateral INO Features Abduction saccades may be slow due to impaired inhibition of medial rectus resting tone. Associated with upward beating and torsional nystagmus. Associated Clinical Features Skew deviation. Defective vertical smooth pursuit. Impairment of the vertical VOR and difficulty suppressing it. Causes of INO Vascular, demyelinating, or metastatic brainstem lesions. Must be differentiated from pseudo-INO caused by myasthenia gravis, paraneoplastic strabismus, or long-standing exotropia. One-and-a-Half Syndrome (Option B): This syndrome results from damage to the caudal pons , which involves both the MLF and either the PPRF or abducens nucleus . It causes gaze palsy (inability to look to one side) in addition to INO . This patient doesn't have a gaze palsy, making one-and-a-half syndrome less likely. Common causes of One-and-a-Half Syndrome include multiple sclerosis, brainstem stroke, primary or metastatic brainstem tumors. Oculomotor nerve palsy (Option C): Would typically present with ptosis, impaired eye movements (including both vertical and horizontal), and possibly dilated pupil. Lateral rectus palsy (Option D): Lateral rectus palsy results in impaired eye abduction, horizontal diplopia, and is most often due to abducens nerve palsy. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th Edition, Page 927

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presents with difficulty moving her eyes to the right. On examination, she is unable to gaze to the right, but has normal eye movements when gazing to the left, up, and down. There is no weakness in the limbs or facial muscles. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Paramedian pontine reticular formation Explanation: The paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) is responsible for coordinating ipsilateral horizontal gaze. A lesion in the right PPRF would impair rightward horizontal gaze, while preserving other directions of eye movement, including vertical gaze. The brainstem contains gaze centers, which are the final common pathways for eye movements. The paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) controls ipsilateral horizontal gaze. PPRF is managed by the frontal eye field (FEF). The midbrain reticular formation (MRF) controls vertical gaze, vergence eye movements, and ocular counter-rolling. These gaze centers receive input from higher brain regions such as the cerebral hemispheres, superior colliculus, vestibular nuclei, and cerebellum. The PPRF and MRF send signals to the three ocular motor nuclei that control eye movements. Supranuclear gaze palsies result from disruption of pathways that carry voluntary saccade and pursuit commands before they reach the brainstem eye movement centers. PPRF lesion: Will lead to ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy. FEF lesion: Will lead to contralateral horizontal gaze palsy. MLF lesion: It is also called Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), it is between the third, fourth and sixth nuclei Left abducens nucleus (Option A): The abducens nucleus controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally. A lesion in the left abducens nucleus would impair the movement of the left eye to the left, but it wouldn't cause an issue with moving both eyes to the right. This would be inconsistent with the patient's inability to move both eyes to the right. Trochlear nerve (Option B): A trochlear nerve lesion results in superior oblique palsy, causing vertical diplopia, especially on downward gaze, and leads to compensatory contralateral head tilt. Right oculomotor nucleus (Option D): The oculomotor nucleus controls the medial rectus (responsible for convergence) and the other muscles that move the eye. A lesion in the right oculomotor nucleus would result in pupil dilation (due to the parasympathetic fibers being affected) and ptosis, as well as problems with eye movement, but not isolated difficulty with horizontal gaze. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th Edition, Page 923, 924

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with blurred vision in her right eye, photophobia and notices that her right pupil appears larger than the left. On examination, her right pupil is mid-dilated and reacts very sluggishly to light and has a sluggish and tonic reaction to accommodation. The left pupil appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Adie’s tonic pupil Explanation: In Adie’s tonic pupil, the affected pupil is abnormally dilated (resulting in isocoria). In this condition, the pupil's response to light is absent, and its reaction to near stimuli is slow and tonic. It is caused by damage to the post-ganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor fibers and is usually unilateral. The affected pupil constricts when treated with weak pilocarpine (0.125%) drops, while the normal pupil does not, due to the denervated iris sphincter becoming supersensitive to parasympathomimetic agents. Pharmacological tests in suspected parasympathetic palsy: The pilocarpine test is used to distinguish between a dilated pupil caused by third nerve palsy, pharmacological mydriasis, or tonic pupil. If the pupil constricts with a low concentration of pilocarpine (0.125%), it indicates Adie’s tonic pupil . If the pupil constricts with the usual concentration of pilocarpine (1-2%), it suggests third nerve palsy . If the pupil does not constrict with pilocarpine, it points to mydriasis due to parasympathetic drug use. Other conditions where the dilated pupil does not react to pilocarpine include traumatic mydriasis and fixed pupils in iritis . For suspected sympathetic palsy , pharmacological tests include: Cocaine test (2-4%) : A small pupil that fails to dilate is indicative of Horner’s syndrome . Hydroxyamphetamine test (1%) : In central or pre-ganglionic Horner's syndrome , the small pupil will dilate, while in post-ganglionic Horner's syndrome , it will not dilate. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pg 965, 966, 968

questions.question: A 30-year-old male has difficulty distinguishing between red and green colours. His occupation requires accurate colour perception. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to quantify and classify the severity of his red-green colour vision deficiency?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nagel Anomaloscope Explanation: The Nagel Anomaloscope is the gold standard for diagnosing and quantifying red-green colour vision deficiencies . The test involves adjusting red and green lights to match a yellow field, which helps in precisely classifying the type and severity of red-green colour blindness. It quantifies both the severity and type of the colour vision defect. Test Procedure Evaluation Applications Lantern Tests (Option D) Individuals identify various coloured lights emitted from a lantern. The accuracy of colour identification is evaluated. Used in occupations requiring accurate colour vision (e.g., aviation, maritime). Example: Edridge-Green lantern. Farnsworth-Munsell 100-Hue Test (Option B) Measures ability to differentiate between subtle colour differences using hue arrangements. A higher error score indicates poorer colour vision. Detects fine colour discrimination errors. Often used to assess toxic optic neuropathy . Ishihara Color Plates (Option A) Coloured dots form numbers or patterns designed to challenge individuals with specific deficiencies. Based on the ability to correctly identify numbers or patterns formed by dots of different colours. Primarily detects red-green colour blindness. Hardy-Rand-Ritter (H-R-R) plates can detect blue-yellow deficiencies . Anomaloscope (Nagel, Pickford-Nicolson) Split visual field: adjust red and green lights to match a yellow field. Determines severity and type of red-green colour vision deficiency through light adjustments. Nagel Anomaloscope for red-green anomalies. Pickford-Nicolson for blue-yellow anomalies. Holmgren’s Wools Test Subject is asked to make a series of colour-matches from a selection of skeins of coloured wools. Based on the ability to correctly match the samples with the reference colours provided. Originally designed to screen red-green colour blindness. Although not a suitable screening test.

questions.question: On examination, a 45-year-old male was found to have repetitive, involuntary horizontal eye movements after looking at a moving striped pattern. He reports no dizziness, and his neurological examination is otherwise unremarkable. The phenomenon he is experiencing is most likely due to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Optokinetic Nystagmus Explanation: Optokinetic nystagmus is a physiological response that occurs when the eyes follow a moving object, like a striped pattern, and then rapidly return to their original position. It is a normal and non-pathological condition. Optokinetic Nystagmus (OKN): Clinical Use Assessing Visual Acuity: Optokinetic nystagmus (OKN) is an objective method for assessing visual acuity, especially in uncooperative patients. A rotating drum with black stripes is shown to the patient, and their eyes follow the stripes with slow, smooth movements (slow phase), snapping back when the stripe disappears (fast phase) . This involuntary reflex indicates proper visual function, and adjustments in stripe width or distance can assess varying acuity levels. Diagnosing Neurological Conditions: Individuals with homonymous hemianopia (loss of vision in half of the visual field) due to parietal lobe lesions do not exhibit a normal optokinetic nystagmus response. This finding indicates that an intact parietal lobe is crucial for the functioning of the optokinetic reflex pathway. Therefore, the absence of OKN in these patients provides insight into potential damage to the neurological pathways involved in visual processing. Gaze-evoked nystagmus (Option A) occurs when the eye is held in an eccentric position, and it is typically seen in cerebellar dysfunction. Vestibular Nystagmus(Option B) is an involuntary movement of the eyes due to vestibular system disturbances, often associated with dizziness or vertigo. Pendular Nystagmus (Option D) is characterised by smooth, sinusoidal oscillations without a slow or fast phase and is usually associated with congenital conditions or visual loss. It does not result from external visual stimuli like a moving striped pattern.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with difficulty moving his eyes upward and convergence-retraction nystagmus triggered by an upward gaze. His pupils react poorly to light but constrict normally when focusing on near objects. Which of the following syndromes is most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Parinaud syndrome Explanation: Parinaud syndrome , also known as dorsal midbrain syndrome , is a neurological condition caused by damage to the dorsal midbrain , specifically affecting the pretectal area and superior colliculus . It results in a distinct set of eye movement abnormalities and is commonly linked to lesions, tumours, or strokes affecting this area. Clinical features and signs: Upgaze Palsy (Vertical Gaze Palsy): Difficulty or inability to move their eyes upward (vertical gaze palsy). Convergence-Retraction Nystagmus: When the patient attempts to look upward, the eyes may instead converge (move inward toward each other) and retract into the orbits Pupillary Light-Near Dissociation: The pupils do not constrict to light but react normally when focusing on a near object (accommodation). Eyelid Retraction (Collier's sign): Abnormally high upper eyelids due to damage in the midbrain. Skew Deviation: Misalignment of the eyes, often vertically. Downward ocular deviation (setting sun sign) Pseudoabducens palsy Weber syndrome (Option B) is caused by a midbrain lesion involving the oculomotor nerve and corticospinal tract, leading to ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiparesis. Benedict syndrome(Option C) involves a lesion in the midbrain affecting the oculomotor nerve and red nucleus, resulting in ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral tremor, and ataxia. Millard-Gubler syndrome (Option D) occurs due to a lesion in the ventral pons, causing ipsilateral facial palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

questions.question: A 50-year-old female patient with anisocoria had cocaine drops applied to both eyes. After 60 minutes, the anisocoria increased. To determine whether the lesion is preganglionic or postganglionic, what is the next step in the diagnostic process?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1% hydroxyamphetamine Explanation: The given scenario is most likely Horner’s syndrome , and to determine the lesion's location, the next best step is to apply 1% hydroxyamphetamine drops. Algorithm for determining the site of lesion in Horner’s syndrome: Cocaine (4%): Block the reuptake of norepinephrine (noradrenaline) normally released from the nerve endings. Hence it dilates the normal pupil (Option A) . Apraclonidine (Option B) : α 2-adrenergic agonist: Miosis in the normal eye. α 1-adrenergic agonist: Mydriasis in Horner’s syndrome (presence of adrenergic denervation supersensitivity) Hydroxyamphetamine (1%) : releases norepinephrine from storage vesicles in the postganglionic sympathetic nerve endings at the iris dilator muscle (Option D) . Postganglionic: No dilation (3rd order nerve is dead). Preganglionic lesion: Dilation Adrenaline (Option C) or Adrenaline 1 in 1000 if used in postganglionic cases then pupils dilate due to denervation supersensitivity. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pg 966, 967.

questions.question: A 48-year-old male with a history of untreated syphilis from several years ago now presents with memory loss, irritability, difficulty walking, and blurred vision. What type of pupil abnormality could be observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Argyll Robertson Pupil Explanation: The given scenario of cognitive and psychotic symptoms with a history of untreated syphilis suggests Neurosyphilis, where Argyll Robertson's pupil is a clinical finding. Abnormal Pupillary Reactions Reaction Description Causes Amaurotic light reflex (Option B) Absence of direct light reflex on the affected side and an absence of consensual light reflex on the normal side. Optic and retinal lesions on the affected side Efferent pathway defect Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. Near reflex is also absent on the affected side. Parasympatholytic drugs (e.g. atropine, homatropine) Internal ophthalmoplegia Third-nerve paralysis. Marcus Gunn pupil or RAPD (Option A) The pupils paradoxically dilate when the flashlight is swung from the unaffected to the affected eye due to the decreased light perception. It is the first sign of optic nerve disorder. Tested by a swinging flashlight test. Incomplete optic nerve lesions (Optic neuritis) and severe retinal diseases (Retinopathy, CRVO) Adie’s Pupil (Option C) Reaction to light is absent, and the near reflex is very slow and tonic. It is usually unilateral, associated with absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women. It shows pupillary constriction to 0.125% Pilocarpine due to denervation supersensitivity. Postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP) (Option D) Reaction to near reflex is present, but light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e. there is light near dissociation. Neurosyphilis Wernicke's hemianopic pupil Light reflex is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side. Optic tract lesion Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Pg 280 Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pg 711 Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page 792,795,796

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient exhibits the following pupillary responses: Light is shown in the left eye; the right pupil constricts, but the left pupil remains dilated. Light is shown in the right eye; only the right pupil constricts, while the left pupil remains dilated. Which of the following lesions is most likely responsible for this pattern of pupillary response?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Left oculomotor nerve Explanation: A lesion in the left oculomotor nerve would disrupt parasympathetic signals to the left iris muscles, preventing the left pupil from constricting. This results in dilating the left pupil regardless of light stimuli , while the right eye's responses remain unaffected. Light Reflex: Direct Light Reflex: Constriction of the pupil in the same eye that is directly exposed to light. Indirect (Consensual) Light Reflex: Constriction of the pupil in the opposite eye when light is shone into one eye. Lesions and their effects of Light Reflex: Optic Nerve (Option A) Direct and consensual reactions are lost on the affected side Both are retained on the opposite side (Option D ruled out) Near reflex and lid reflex remain intact. Medial Chiasma Bitemporal hemianopia Lateral Chiasma Binasal hemianopia. Optic Tract Contralateral hemianopia; Wernicke reaction. Proximal Optic Tract Normal pupillary reactions Central Decussation Bilateral reflex paralysis with no reaction to light but retention of near reflex, lid reflexes, and psycho-sensory reactions Argyll Robertson pupil. Nuclear / Supranuclear Lesion (Option B) Ipsilateral absolute pupillary paralysis. Third Nerve Lesion Absolute pupillary paralysis. Ciliary Ganglion Lesion The light reflex is abolished, but the retention of the near reflex is sometimes followed by tonic contraction (Adie pupil).

questions.question: A 62-year-old patient with papilledema has been examined. On fundoscopic examination of the eye obscuration of major blood vessels is found on the disc & vessels leaving the disc, with a significant halo around the disc. According to the Frisen grading system, what is the grade of papilledema?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Grade 4 Explanation: In the Frisen grading system, Grade 4 is characterised by the obscuration of major vessels on the disc. Although vessels that leave the disc are also obscured, which corresponds to Grade 3, the overall presentation falls under Grade 4 . Grading of Papilledema (Modified Frisen Scale) Grade 1 : C-shaped halo nasally. Grade 2 : Circumferential halo around the optic disc. Grade 3 : Obscuration of one or more major vessels leaving the disc. Grade 4 : Obscuration of major vessels on the disc. Grade 5 : Complete obscuration of all vessels on and leaving the disc

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient presents with worsening headaches and visual disturbances. Fundoscopic examination reveals optic disc swelling. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?

options.C: Blurring of the optic disc margins

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Increased cup-to-disc ratio Explanation: Papilledema typically presents with blurring of the optic disc margins, enlargement of the blind spot, and engorged and tortuous retinal veins. As the disc swells, the physiological cup size usually decreases . An increased cup-to-disc ratio is more indicative of glaucomatous changes rather than papilledema . Papilloedema: Swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure Characteristic Features: Passive oedema without inflammation. Swelling primarily in the optic nerve head in front of the lamina cribrosa. Engorged, tortuous small blood vessels (Option D) and swollen nerve fibres. Axoplasmic stasis with swollen, disrupted mitochondria. Retinal changes include macular star and cotton-wool spots . Signs: Initial blurring of optic disc margins. (Option C) Enlargement of the blind spot due to the separation of the retina. (Option B) Hyperaemia, swelling, and engorgement of disc vessels. Potential for haemorrhages, exudates, and macular star formation. Chronic cases may lead to optic atrophy and visual loss. Stages of Papilledema: Stages Description Early Papilledema Blurring of optic disc margins, disc hyperemia, and mild disc swelling. Normal visual field & acuity. Fully Developed Papilledema Significant optic disc elevation, engorged veins, and peripapillary haemorrhages. Transient disturbance of vision. Chronic Papilledema Disc cup obliteration, reduced hyperemia, and hard exudates Visual acuity decreases, & Constriction of the visual field. Late Papilledema Optic atrophy, reduced disc swelling, and a grey, blurred disc appearance. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Pg - 842,843 Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pg - 883

questions.question: A 62-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion affecting the visual pathway?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Left Optic tract Explanation: The clinical presentation of difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes indicates a visual field defect known as Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Optic Tract. Visual Pathway: Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field. Components of Visual Pathway Retina First-order Neurons : Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina. Second-order Neurons : Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve. Optic Nerve Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm. Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye. Optic Chiasma Partial decussation occurs Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side , while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral. Optic Tract Carries visual information from the optic chiasms to the Lateral Gebiculate body(LGB). Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye. The lesion causes Homonymous Hemianopia in the opposite eye . Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB) Third Order Neurons : Relay visual information to the visual cortex. Optic Radiations Meyer's Loop : Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex. Baum’s Loop (Dorsal) : Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex. Occipital Cortex The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure .

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient with multiple sclerosis (MS) notices that her vision becomes temporarily blurred whenever she exercises. Which of the following phenomena is most likely explained by this temporary worsening of neurological symptoms due to increased body temperature?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Uhthoff's Phenomenon Explanation: Uhthoff's Phenomenon refers to the temporary worsening of neurological symptoms in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) due to increased body temperature. Mechanism: In MS, the immune system attacks the myelin sheath, leading to demyelination and impaired nerve conduction. Elevated body temperature exacerbates this impairment by further affecting the conduction of nerve signals through heat-sensitive demyelinated axons, resulting in a transient conduction block. Symptoms: Blurring of vision during activities like hot showers or exercise. Increased muscle weakness during a fever. Worsening of balance or coordination after exposure to heat. Resolution: Symptoms typically resolve once body temperature returns to normal. Riddoch's Phenomenon (Option A) refers to a visual disturbance where a patient can perceive movement but not static objects, typically resulting from damage to the occipital lobe. Pulfrich's Phenomenon (Option C) is a visual anomaly where objects moving in a straight line appear to follow a curved trajectory due to delayed visual processing. It is often associated with optic neuritis but is not related to heat or temperature changes. Lhermitte sign (Option D) is a transient electric shock-like sensation that travels down the spine and often into the limbs when the neck is flexed forward . It is seen in MS. Reference: Harrison’s Internal Medicine textbook 21st Ed pg- 3463 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470244/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive bilateral vision loss over the past few months. He reports a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption. Examination reveals a centrocecal scotoma in both eyes, and fundoscopy shows mild temporal pallor of the optic discs, as shown in the image. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cyanide Explanation: Cyanide is a well-established cause of toxic amblyopia , also known as tobacco-alcohol amblyopia . Cyanide, specifically from tobacco smoke , inhibits mitochondrial enzymes, particularly the cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain, leading to a lack of ATP and optic nerve dysfunction . Retinal ganglion cells, being energy-dependent, are especially vulnerable to cyanide’s toxic effects, causing progressive vision loss . The patient's history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption increases the likelihood of cyanide exposure. The characteristic bilateral vision loss and centrocecal scotoma on fundoscopy are consistent with cyanide toxicity. Agents Causing Toxic Amblyopia: Toxic amblyopia results from damage to the optic nerve or retinal ganglion cells due to various exogenous, endogenous, or drug-related causes. The following agents are known to cause toxic amblyopia : Category Agents Mechanism of Action Exogenous Poisons Tobacco (Cyanide), Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol), Methyl Alcohol (Methanol), Ethylene Glycol (Antifreeze), Lead, Arsenic, Cannabis indica (Tetrahydrocannabinol), Carbon Disulfide (Industrial Solvent) These toxins directly affect optic nerve function through mitochondrial dysfunction or systemic toxicity. Medications Digoxin, Disulfiram, Isoniazid, Chloroquine, Cyanide, Ethambutol, Quinine, Streptomycin, Amiodarone, Sulfasalazine,

questions.question: A 72-year-old patient presents with sudden vision loss in one eye, severe headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication. Fundoscopic examination reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with haemorrhages. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR and CRP levels. What is the diagnosis and the appropriate management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Arteritic AION; High dose corticosteroids Explanation: Arteritic AION is often related to Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) and presents with systemic symptoms such as severe headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication . It requires prompt treatment with high-dose corticosteroids to manage inflammation and prevent further vision loss. Feature Arteritic AION (AAION) Non-Arteritic AION (NAION) Cause Inflammation and potential blood clot formation due to Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) No inflammatory process; unclear reason for blood vessel blockage Prevalence 5-10% of AION cases 90-95% of AION cases Typical Age Around 70 years Middle-aged to older adults (usually over 50) Risk Factors Age > 50 Northern European descent Other autoimmune diseases Diabetes Hypertension Atherosclerosis Crowded optic disc Symptoms Severe headache Scalp tenderness Jaw claudication Systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue Sudden vision loss (painless) Altitudinal field defect Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD) Ophthalmoscopic Findings Pale and swollen optic disc Cotton wool spots Splinter haemorrhages Swollen and hyperemic optic disc Visual Field Defect Inferior altitudinal defects are common Diagnostic Tests Elevated ESR and CRP Temporal artery biopsy Fluorescein angiography Visual field testing Management High-dose corticosteroids Long-term low-dose corticosteroids No proven treatment Manage risk factors through lifestyle modifications Low-dose aspirin (can be used sometimes)

questions.question: A 48-year-old woman presents with a history of decreased vision in her right eye. On examining the right eye, there is RAPD, pain on eye elevation, and the fundus is normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) High-dose Corticosteroids Explanation: The patient’s symptoms and clinical findings are consistent with acute retrobulbar optic neuritis , commonly associated with demyelination in multiple sclerosis. While spontaneous recovery can occur , IV methylprednisolone is recommended to reduce inflammation, shorten symptom duration, and decrease the risk of future attacks, especially in high-risk patients. Management of Optic neuritis Treatment Indications Details Conservative management (Observation and Monitoring) Mild symptoms Known history of similar episodes Many cases improve spontaneously. Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes. High-Dose Corticosteroids Severe vision loss No history of previous episodes MRI evidence of demyelination Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial). It accelerates visual recovery but does not prevent future multiple sclerosis episodes. Patients with optic neuritis when related to MS can also be given Glatiramer acetate and Beta Interferon 1a. Oral antibiotics (Option C) are typically used to treat bacterial infections. While optic neuritis can be associated with infections, such as neuroretinitis, antibiotics would only be appropriate if there is clear evidence of a bacterial infection. Surgical intervention (Option D) is not indicated in the management of optic neuritis. While surgery, such as optic nerve sheath decompression, may be considered in other optic nerve conditions like papilledema, it is not appropriate for optic neuritis. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Pg 865

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of difficulty in vision in her left eye, along with persistent headaches and occasional eye pain. She also reports trouble with colour perception. Fundoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. Which type of optic neuritis is most likely to be seen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Neuroretinitis Explanation: The clinical scenario with a macular star in fundoscopy suggests Neuroretinitis , a subtype of optic neuritis. Optic neuritis is an inflammatory condition of the optic nerve that can cause vision loss, with symptoms including decreased vision, pain in eye movement, and visual field defects. Classification of Optic neuritis: Papillitis (Option A) Retrobulbar Neuritis (Option B) Neuroretinitis (Option C) Site Optic disc Optic nerve behind the eyeball. Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area. Characteristic features Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated. Pain on eye elevation RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed. Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc , at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “ the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing ” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis. A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids). Clinical

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman has a 6-month history of worsening vision and difficulty with detailed tasks, along with occasional eye pain in her left eye. Fundoscopy shows a chalky white optic disc with normal vessels in her left eye. What is the most common cause of these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Multiple sclerosis Explanation: The given scenario suggests Primary optic atrophy, with multiple sclerosis being the most common cause. Optic Atrophy: It is the degeneration of the optic nerve, which occurs as an end result of any pathologic process that damages axons in the anterior visual system. Classification of Optic atrophy: Primary Secondary Consecutive Glaucomatous Pathology Refers to the degeneration of the nerve fibres Seen in the retrolaminar area. Occurs following any pathologic condition or disease. Occurs following destruction of ganglion cells secondary to lesions of the choroid and/ or retina Occurs due to long-standing glaucoma. Etiology Multiple sclerosis (Option B) Retrobulbar neuritis Leber's hereditary optic atrophies Intracranial tumours (e.g. pituitary tumours) Traumatic severance or avulsion of the optic nerve Toxic amblyopia (chronic retrobulbar neuritis) Tabes dorsalis. Long-standing optic nerve disease. Papilledema (Option A) Diffuse chorioretinitis Retinal pigmentary dystrophies (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa (Option C) , pathological myopia and occlusion of the central retinal artery) Glaucoma (Option D) Fundoscopy Chalky white Clear disc margin Lamina cribrosa well seen Normal vessels. Dirty grey Clear disc margin Lamina cribrosa obscured Peripapillary sheathing over vessels Hyaline bodies on the retina. Waxy pallor Blurred disc margin Lamina cribrosa well seen Attenuated vessels Characterized by deep and wide cupping of the optic disc and nasal shift of the blood vessels.

questions.question: A 45-year-old female reports a gradual decline in vision in her right eye over the past three months, accompanied by blurry vision and impaired colour perception in that eye. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist suspected optic nerve damage and advised further tests. Which of the following manifestations does not indicate optic nerve dysfunction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Positive scotoma Explanation: A positive scotoma is a visual field defect that is perceived by the patient as something seen abnormally like a dark patch and is commonly associated with macular lesions. Optic nerve dysfunction is usually associated with negative scotoma. Optic nerve damage presents with dyschromatopsia, central scotoma, and contrast sensitivity decreases. Manifestations of Optic nerve dysfunction Visual loss can be gradual and sudden, depending on the cause. Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn Pupil The pupils paradoxically dilate when the flashlight is swung from the unaffected to the affected eye due to the decreased light perception. It is caused by incomplete optic nerve lesions and severe retinal diseases. It is the first sign of optic nerve disorder and can be tested by swinging flashlight test. Dyschromatopsia: Impairment of colour vision (Option B) . There is a decrease in, Visual activity Brightness Contrast sensitivity (Option D) Visual field defects include, Central scotoma (most common) (Option C) Centrocecal scotoma Altitudinal field defect

questions.question: Which of the following arteries contributes to the formation of the Circle of Zinn-Haller?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Short posterior ciliary artery Explanation: The Circle of Zinn or Circle of Zinn-Haller is primarily formed by the short posterior ciliary arteries, which supply the optic nerve head. Optic nerve: The optic nerve (2nd Cranial nerve) starts from the optic disc and extends up to the optic chiasma, where the two nerves meet. Blood supply of optic nerve: Circle of Zinn (also called Circle of Zinn-Haller) : Formed by anastomosis of the short posterior ciliary artery. Central retinal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery) The central retinal artery (Option A) supplies the inner 6 layers of the optic disc. It does not contribute to the formation of the Circle of Zinn. The ophthalmic artery (Option B) , along with the choroidal arteries, circle of Zinn, and central retinal artery, contributes to the formation of the pial plexus.

questions.question: A 62-year-old patient presents with a visual field defect following a stroke. Neuroimaging reveals a lesion in the occipital lobe related to the territory of the posterior cerebral artery affecting the calcarine cortex. Which of the following visual field characteristics is most likely associated with this type of lesion?

options.A: Congruous Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing
options.B: Congruous Homonymous Hemianopia without Macular Sparing
options.C: Incongruous homonymous hemianopia with Macular sparing
options.D: Incongruous homonymous hemianopia without Macular sparing

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Congruous Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing Explanation: A lesion in the occipital lobe, specifically in the Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) territory affecting the calcarine cortex, typically causes congruous homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. This characteristic defect arises because the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is the major artery supplying the primary visual cortex, while the macula is protected by its blood supply from middle cerebral artery (MCA). Lesions in Visual Cortex: Typically present as congruous homonymous hemianopia (visual field loss is consistent in both eyes). Blood supply of Visual Cortex: The primary visual cortex, mainly supplied by the posterior cerebral artery (PCA), processes visual information, and a PCA stroke can lead to homonymous hemianopia. Macular Area : Located at the posterior tip of the visual cortex and is crucial for detailed central vision. Its dual blood supply (from both PCA and MCA) helps to protect it from complete loss even when there is an isolated PCA lesion. (Macular Sparing) . Injury to the tip of the visual cortex leads to Macular Homonymous Hemianopia .

questions.question: A 58-year-old patient presents with visual disturbances. Neuroimaging reveals a lesion in the temporal lobe affecting the inferior optic radiations. Which visual field defects are most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Superior homonymous quadrantanopia Explanation: A lesion affecting the inferior optic radiations, particularly in Meyer’s loop within the temporal lobe, typically results in superior homonymous quadrantanopia. Optic Radiation: A neural pathway that transmits visual information from the lateral geniculate body to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Aspect Inferior Optic Radiations (Meyer’s Loop) Superior Optic Radiations (Baum’s Loop) Location of Lesion Temporal lobe Parietal lobe Affected Visual Field Superior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes Inferior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes. Visual Defect Superior homonymous quadrantanopia Inferior homonymous quadrantanopia (Option A) Associated Symptoms Memory loss Hearing loss Auditory hallucinations Contralateral hemiplegia Hemianesthesia Optokinetic nystagmus Central scotoma (Option C) is a defect in central vision that is typically associated with lesions in the retina, optic nerve, and macula rather than the specific pathways in the temporal lobe. Homonymous hemianopia (Option D) occurs in lesions involving the optic tract, lateral geniculate body (LGB), or both superior and inferior optic radiations.

questions.question: A 58-year-old patient presents with right-sided visual field loss in both eyes, resulting in a homonymous hemianopic defect. Neuroimaging and clinical examination suggest a lesion affecting the visual pathway. Based on the above findings, which anatomical location is most likely implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Left optic tract Explanation: A lesion in the left optic tract would cause right (contralateral) homonymous hemianopia, where the right visual field is lost in both eyes. Location of the lesion Characteristic features Optic nerve Marked loss of vision or complete blindness on the affected side associated. Near (accommodation) reflex is present. Optic chiasma Bitemporal hemianopia Optic tract Contralateral homonymous hemianopia Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction. Optic radiations Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky) Produced when the inferior fibres (Meyer’s loop) are involved in temporal lobe lesions) Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor) Produced when superior fibres (Baum’s loop) are involved in parietal lobe lesions. Visual cortex Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

questions.question: A 64-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects. MRI findings reveal a pituitary adenoma causing compression at the optic chiasma. Which visual field defect is most likely associated with this condition? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bitemporal Hemianopia Explanation: A pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm typically results in Bitemporal hemianopia due to the involvement of crossing nasal fibres of the optic nerves, causing loss of vision in the outer portions of both visual fields. Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects Site of Lesion Fibers Affected Field Defect Optic Nerve Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers Anopia Optic Chiasma Bilateral Nasal Fibers Bitemporal Hemianopia (Heteronymous Hemianopia) Optic Tract Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB Lesion) Optic Radiation Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers Homonymous Hemianopia (Option C) Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip (Post. Cerebral Artery) Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing (Option D) Tip of Visual Cortex (Middle Cerebral Artery) Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers. Macular Homonymous Hemianopia Pie in the Sky (Option B) (Superior Homonymous Quadrantanopia) occurs in Lesion of Inferior Optic Radiation.
